channel.title: Torrenting...The risk?
channel.description: What is the risk of torrenting halo pc and fate 1 & 2? Im not going to torrent for a long time now but what is the risk?

item.title: Torrenting...The risk?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“masta XY, post:49, topic:249743”][quote author=Wrauld link=topic=329187.msg2600371#msg2600371 date=1230187638]

Poor Australia.
Comcast should make an office building there/business, you’d guys would love it.

Comcast sucks… i got High speed internet by AT&T… my speed for uploading and downloading= uploading- 1.3mb/s downloading- 2.4mb/s its really fast for only $41.89/monthly (USD) but this was after the update for the phone service to the 3G network, and the upgrade on the process of the internet services when they got complaint’s about it being down… Now they are America’s number one 3G network, and most reliable internet service…

uploading speed for me is like 6mb/s and like download is somewhere around 20-30mb/s…I think it really depends where you live though.
[/quote]

Small town here, closest AT&T store= 1.5 hour’s away. Rofl.[/quote]
Here I live you can get 50000/50000 Kb/s, and its not a big place.

Read full topic

item.title: Torrenting...The risk?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:42, topic:249743”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=329187.msg2597260#msg2597260 date=1230041350]

I forgot my PC on for 6 weeks during the school holidays, and it managed to upload 1.3TB.

Ouch.
[/quote]That’s awesome unless you are in ausfagland. More seeding == more download quota.

What? Really, that would be good. So the more you seed, the more you can download? Wow.

If I did that in Australia, my internet would be 28.2kb/s for a month -.-

28.2 Kbits?
Thats should be illegal to give someone Internet lower than 1000/200 Kbits.

I grew up on dialup and if I was really lucky, I could get 1 kB/s. Most of the time I settled for ~0.5 kB/s. Programs like napstar would rarely exceed 0.2 kB/s.

Then when one of my friends was getting 5 kB/s download speeds I was so retardedly jealous.[/quote]
Yes I know how bad Dial-Up was, we had it until 2005, it sucks.
Thats the reason it should be illegal.

Read full topic

Then when one of my friends was getting 5 kB/s download speeds I was so retardedly jealous.

item.title: Torrenting...The risk?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:39, topic:249743”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=329187.msg2596157#msg2596157 date=1230000263]

I forgot my PC on for 6 weeks during the school holidays, and it managed to upload 1.3TB.

Ouch.
[/quote]That’s awesome unless you are in ausfagland. More seeding == more download quota.

What? Really, that would be good. So the more you seed, the more you can download? Wow.

If I did that in Australia, my internet would be 28.2kb/s for a month -.-

That cannot be right, cause with my dads internet which only has 100kbit upload, it is able to download torrents at 3mbits…

Do you mean that upload gives you transfer back, like if you upload 10gb on a 10gb download plan, you then have 20gb to download that month?[/quote]
The latter.

item.title: Torrenting...The risk?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Yz85Racer:

I wasn’t aware torrenting was illegal, well not illegal enough to worry.

Torrenting is not illegal. Linux isos and various other software is mass-distributed via torrents every day and is perfectly legal. Distributing illegal or pirated software is illegal no matter how you do it.

Read full topic

item.title: Torrenting...The risk?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:26, topic:249743”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=329187.msg2582652#msg2582652 date=1229307535]
Unless they count both upload and download, which many do. You don’t give back to rapidshare
[/quote]

the decent thing about rapidshare is that it uses port 8080 (internet) so they can only see what sites you visited and files, if the file is named backup018.rar and is 700mb, how will they know the difference?

but if your using a different port (torrenting) it is alot easier to monitor, i know my university blocks most ports[/quote]
Our school are also blocking most ports, or its look more like its block all ports except some allowed ports.
Also blocking downloads of Torrents. (Are the some way to torrent without lose the good speed.)

You live in USA, so downloading files can give you much problem if MRAA or RIAA sues you.
They sues you if they see you downloading files. They do that by torrenting self and see who the peers is.
Most ISP does care what you do, except when Police or RIAA tell them to do that.

Read full topic

item.title: Torrenting...The risk?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Mopman:

Unless they count both upload and download, which many do. You don’t give back to rapidshare

the decent thing about rapidshare is that it uses port 8080 (internet) so they can only see what sites you visited and files, if the file is named backup018.rar and is 700mb, how will they know the difference?

but if your using a different port (torrenting) it is alot easier to monitor, i know my university blocks most ports

Read full topic
